abstracts.cdata!:
In the light of the prevailing country
            practices and conditions and with the objective of aligning
            better with the country systems, there will be an extension
            of the timeline of the submission of the audits in the India
            portfolio from six to nine months for all active projects,
            starting with audit report due for FY2015. All future
            projects will continue to use the flexibility provided by
            OP/BO 10.00 in terms of determining the timing of the audit.
            This proposal to extend the date of submission of annual
            audit reports to nine months across the active India
            portfolio is being processed in response to India’s request
            dated 21-January-2015.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Carbon Tetrachloride (CTC) Sector
            Phase-out Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Carbon Tetrachloride
            (CTC) Sector Phase-out Project for India were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risk to global environment
            outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            project design should be kept simple even if the issues are
            complex. Continuance of key staff in linked and programmatic
            operations facilitates effective implementation. More
            structured co-ordination between the various multilateral
            and bilateral agencies enhances effectiveness. Long-term
            partnership between the World Bank and Industrial
            Development Bank of India Limited (IDBI) in ozone depleting
            substance (ODS) phase-out served a big advantage. Relating
            to the use of a financial intermediary, IDBI's role was
            strategic in facilitating a seamless financial and
            disbursement and technical link between beneficiaries and
            the ozone cell (OC) thereby enabling the OC to focus on the
            broader policy reform, donor collaboration, overall
            monitoring and reporting to the Bank, and the multilateral
            fund for the implementation of the Montreal protocol (MP)
            (MLF). Regarding the project design, the performance-based
            disbursement where funds are released on annual basis based
            on pre-determined phase-out schedules and verified targets
            did provide an excellent implementation structure which
            served as a motivation and incentive to stakeholders and
            beneficiaries to find cost effective ways of phasing out
            production and use of CTC. The programmatic approach of
            using a CTC sector plan framed within a national ODS-phase
            out framework lent itself to effective planning and
            supervision which helped in generating higher level
            sustainable results.
